attributes.title: Study 3 - Judging accuracy in eyewitness testimony (Experiment 2)

q1.value: Judging accuracy in eyewitness testimony - Experiment 2

q2.value: Philip Gustafsson, Torun Lindholm, Fredrik Jönsson

q3.value:
Eyewitness testimonies are often critical in crime investigations and ensuing trials (Wells et al., 2006). However, eyewitness evidence is also found to be unreliable, as some witnesses lie (see DePaulo et al., 2003; Sporer and Schwandt, 2006; Vrij et al., 2017), and perhaps more commonly, provide honest but erroneous accounts. Indeed, the hazard of eyewitness evidence becomes quite clear as it is estimated that more than 70% of overturned wrongful convictions involved eyewitness misidentifications (innocenceproject.org; see also Garrett, 2011). 

While eyewitness reports may be problematic, it is important to highlight that incorrect testimonies may not necessarily be detrimental. The negative consequences that may follow from an incorrect memory recall can be avoided if the error is detected. It is therefore crucial for fact finders to obtain the skill to separate correct from incorrect testimonies. Research shows that there is room for improvement of this skill (e.g. Ball & O'Callaghan, 2001; Clark-Foos, Brewer & Marsh, 2015; Johnson & Suengas, 1989; Lindholm 2005; 2008a; 2008b; Schooler, Gerhard & Loftus, 1986). 

Recently, we put forth evidence for a new method to judge eyewitness evidence (Lindholm, Jönsson & Tullio-Liuzza, 2018; Gustafsson, Lindholm & Jönsson, 2019). This method is based on a witness’ verbal and paraverbal expressions of effort when attempting to remember the event. In our studies, witnesses showed indications of effort, like pausing and using interjections such as “eh”, “uh”, more often when the details they recalled were incorrect rather than correct. 

The current study is a follow-up to a previous experiment where we investigated whether this new method could be incorporated into fact finders’ judgments, in order to improve their skill in judging the accuracy of eyewitness testimonies. The results of this previous experiment showed no significant effect of participants having been informed about the relation between retrieval effort and memory accuracy (i.e., effort-instruction) on accuracy judgments of eyewitness testimonies, as compared to when they had not been informed. One potential explanation for this finding is that participants may have only partially relied on this information, and combined it with their own cues to memory accuracy. We explored this idea by examining whether judgment performance would improve if statements were judged for accuracy by exclusively using the two effort cues hedges and pauses. Hence, we scored all witness statements with hedges or pauses as incorrect, and statement without these cues as correct.  Support for this idea was found by comparing participants’ judgments to an “ideal effort observer” that coded accuracy of statements completely based on the effort instruction. Using this strict criterion resulted in better judgment accuracy compared to participants in the experimental group. This indicates that it might be possible to improve judgments if the participants exclusively base their judgments on these two cues. In the current study will use instructions where we strongly emphasize that participants in the experimental group should only rely on the two suggested cues.

Furthermore, in the current study, participants will judge one of three different eyewitness testimonies. These testimonies have been chosen to represent three different effort-accuracy ratios. That is, one testimony has a large negative effort-accuracy ratio, with few effort cues in correct statements and many effort cues in incorrect statements. Another testimony has a medium negative effort-accuracy ratio, and the final testimony has a small positive effort-accuracy ratio (i.e. more effort in correct statements than incorrect statements. These three ratios represent the mean and two extremes of the testimonies in the previous experiment.

q4.value: We expect an interaction between instruction group and witness testimony on judgment accuracy. Specifically, we expect participants to be most accurate in their judgments of the  testimony that has a large negative effort-accuracy ratio, less accurate in judging the  testimony with a medium negative effort-accuracy ratio and least accurate in judging the testimony with a small positive effort-accuracy ratio. We expect this effect to be greater for participants in the experimental group compared to participants in the control group.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value: We have a 2 (instruction: effort cue instruction/ "do your best" instruction) x 3 (eyewitness testimony: large negative effort-accuracy ratio/medium negative effort-accuracy ratio/small positive effort-accuracy ratio) between subjects design.

q9.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to instruction group and eyewitness testimony using simple randomization.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited at universities in the Stockholm area, as well as from advertising on the research volunteering website www.studentkaninen.se. Participants that have previously participated in studies at Stockholm University in which they have been interviewed as eyewitnesses, or judged the accuracy of eyewitness statements, will be excluded.

q13.value: We have planned a sample of N=158 with 79 participants per instruction group, and 52 participants per witness testimony.

q14.value: We expect a power level of 80% given a medium effect size and alpha level .05. The effect size is estimated from an optimization of the design from the previous experiment.

question.value:
We manipulate the "instruction" variable. The experimental group (effort cue condition) will receive the information that "incorrect eyewitness statements more often than correct statements contain: 1) pauses longer than two seconds, and 2) hedges, that is, expressions that diminish the strength of a statements, e.g. 'maybe', 'could have been', 'I think'. These participants are then instructed to use this information as a basis for their judgments of accuracy. The control group ("do your best" condition) will not receive the information about pauses and hedges, but are instead asked to judge accuracy based on their own knowledge regarding differences between correct and incorrect statements. 

The "eyewitness testimony" variable is varied by showing each participant one of three different eyewitness testimonies, which vary in the ratio of effort cues in correct and incorrect statements.

The main outcome variable will be participants' ability to distinguish the accuracy of the eyewitness statements, measured as d' (signal detection theory). This value will be obtained by calculating the hits, misses, false alarms, and correct rejections for each judgment the participants make. The judgments will be measured by having the participants answer either "correct" or "incorrect" for each eyewitness testimony statement. 

The testimonies used in this study come from a previous study by Gustafsson, Lindholm & Jönsson (2019), where the accuracy of each eyewitness statement has already been coded (correct/incorrect).

We calculate d' using signal detection theory: d' = z(False alarm rate) - z(Hit rate) 
We will also look at response bias, "c", calculated with the following formula: c = (z(Hit rate) + z (False alarm rate)) / 2

We will use Signal Detection Theory to calculate d’ for the accuracy of each participant's judgments. We will then carry out an ANOVA with accuracy of the judgment (d’) as dependent variable and instruction and eyewitness testimony as independent variables. This ANOVA will include an interaction between instruction and eyewitness testimony in order to test our hypothesis.

q21.value: Significance testing, cutoff at p = .05. Two tailed test.

q24.value: We will look at sensitivity bias in an exploratory way, as we do not expect any group to be more biased in their judgments (i.e. more likely to say correct than incorrect, or vice versa).

attributes.title: Does Interdependent Self-Construal Moderate the Relationship between Shame and Unacceptable Thoughts

q1.value: Does Interdependent Self-Construal Moderate the Relationship between Shame and Unacceptable Thoughts

q3.value: Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is a debilitating psychological condition and one form of OCD that is particularly distressing and difficult to treat involves obsessive concerns about unacceptable thoughts.  Previous research has shown that issues of self and identity play a role in producing shame and distress for these unacceptable thoughts.  However, no study thus far has explored the role of culture and how it influences shame for these unacceptable thoughts. The study aims to examine whether culturally influenced concepts of the self (independent vs interdependent) affects the relationship between shame and unacceptable thoughts among individuals in the community recruited from GP practice. These community samples are accepted as an analogue to study OCD because past research has shown that obsessive-compulsive symptoms also exist along a continuum in individuals across the general community. The results of this study will add to the current understanding of the role of culture and identity on emotional experiences in OCD with unacceptable thoughts.

q4.value: Only recently has research been established around shame’s role in OCD. Cultural aspect of the self-construal and its influence on the relationship between shame and OCD has not been explored within the current literature. Therefore, the primary purpose of this study is to address whether interdependent self-construal moderates the relationship between shame and intrusive/unacceptable thoughts to provide and add to the current literature in better understanding the cultural role of the self-construal in the relationship between shame and intrusive thoughts. It is hypothesised that shame is positively associated with intrusive thoughts and is moderated by interdependent self-construal. The interaction between interdependent self-construal and shame would be such that the relationship between shame and unacceptable thoughts would be stronger amongst individuals with higher levels of interdependent self-construal even after controlling for depressive symptomologies. It is predicted that there is a strong positive relationship between depressive symptomologies and unacceptable thoughts scores amongst individuals.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Bivariate Correlation zero-order will be conducted to examine the strength of the relationship between all variables. Hierarchical multiple regression (moderation analysis) was conducted to examine whether the moderator (interdependent self-construal) changes the relationship between the predictor (shame) and the outcome (unacceptable thoughts) whilst controlling for depressive symptomologies. Analysis will be conducted using SPSS v25 and Hayes’ PROCESS v3 macro. The dependent variable is severity of OCD related to unacceptable thoughts. The predictor variables are shame, interdependent self-construal and depression will be evaluated as a covariate. All predictor variables will be mean-centred. The interaction term will be will fitted to these centred variables.

q9.value: snowball sampling recruitment will be utilised for the GP practice.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: A power analysis for a hierarchical multiple regression was conducted to examine the sample size required to detect the interaction effect after accounting for three predictors (interdependent self-construal, shame and depression) at alpha level at 0.05 and power at .95, and an estimated medium effect size. The power analysis showed that a minimum sample of 89 participants. The proposed sample size of 200 participants will thus be sufficient.

question.value:
Procedure
Permission from GP practices in Adelaide and Sydney will be sought and a flyer will be posted at these GP practices. Interested participants will approach the practice manager for the participant information letter which will have a direct link to MTurk online participation to ensure confidentiality. Participants will also have the option to request the survey directly from the GP Practice Manager and upon completion participants return the survey to the Practice Manager in a sealed envelope. As the questionnaire has 48 items, participation will take approximately 10 mins. 
Recruitment of participants from crowdsourcing website (e.g., MTurk) will be used to broaden the sample and to ensure sufficient number of participants in the study.  Crowdsourced participants will be paid US$1.50 to complete the questionnaire.  Registered Users of Amazon Mechanical Turk are assigned a unique and individual identification number and only non-identifiable information will be collected. 
Ethical Consideration
Permission to approach patients in the GP practices will be sought from the Manager of the General Medical Practices. Confidentiality will be assured as questionnaires are non-identifiable. Participants will be provided with an explanatory statement in the participant information letter. Participants will be advised that their participation is voluntary and that they may opt out at any point during the study. The study relies on self-report measures and therefore participants responses will be non-identifiable. Participants will indicate on the questionnaire that they have read the participant information letter and that they agree to participate.  Consent is implied upon completion and return of the questionnaires. 
Finally, the questionnaires contain items that may distress participants as many items concern negative emotions and mental health problems. However, these questionnaires are commonly used in clinical and non-clinical samples and are well tolerated.  Information about counselling services in relevant areas will be provided in the PIL.

Hierarchical multiple regression (moderation analysis) was conducted to examine whether the moderator (interdependent self-construal) changes the relationship between the predictor (shame) and the outcome (unacceptable thoughts) whilst controlling for depressive symptomologies. Analysis will be conducted using SPSS v25 and Hayes’ PROCESS v3 macro. The dependent variable is severity of OCD related to unacceptable thoughts. The predictor variables are shame, interdependent self-construal and depression will be evaluated as a covariate. All predictor variables will be mean-centred. The interaction term will be will fitted to these centred variables.

q20.value: cases will b recorded under the heading predictors ( interdependent self-construal, shame, unacceptable thoughts and depression). Outliers will be transformed through a statical method called Winsorization. This approach involves modifying outliers or replacing the values being tested for outliers with expected values. The weight modification method allows weight modification without discarding or replacing the values of outliers, limiting the influence of the outliers. The value modification method allows the replacement of the values of outliers with the largest or second smallest value .All predictor variables will be mean-centred. The interaction term will be fitted to these centred variables.

q21.value: Two tailed test, at alpha at 0.05 and power at .95, and an estimated medium effect size.

q22.value: cases that have missing responses will be deleted. Outliers will be transformed using the winsorization method to ensure outliers are appropriately analysed

q23.value: cases with incomplete data will be deleted.

q24.value: Even though we are examining primarily interdependent self construal and its relationship to shame and unacceptable thoughts. The study will also collect data on independent self-construal and we may also examine how it relates to the relationship between shame and unacceptable thoughts.

attributes.title: Can Avatars Using Your Face Persuade You to Like AIs? The Effects of Pro or Anti-AI Messages Delivered Through Different Modalities of Communication

q1.value: Can Avatars Using Your Face Persuade You to Like AIs? The Effects of Pro or Anti-AI Messages Delivered Through Different Modalities of Communication

q3.value: This study examines how playback of pro or anti-AI persuasive messages through different delivery conditions (i.e., avatar with subject's face, avatar with a stranger's face, audio) affects individual's attitudes about AI, along with their self-perception. The study will also examine how uncanny valley perceptions can moderate and/or mediate the effects of pro or anti-AI persuasive messages in different delivery conditions.

q4.value:
H1  Participants exposed to Self and Stranger-TalkingHead playback conditions will exhibit increased (a) AI-generated message identification; (b) uncanny valley perceptions; (c) extended parallel process model responses; (d) enjoyment of the experimental task; (e) self-awareness; (f) AI trust; and (g) AI folk theory scores; but decreased (h) bias against AIs, relative to participants in the Audio playback condition.

This hypothesis will be explored with orthogonal contrasts; Self and Stranger-TalkingHead playback conditions will both be assigned +1, while the Audio playback condition will be assigned -2.

H2  Participants exposed to the Self-TalkingHead playback condition will show increased (a) AI-generated message identification; (b) uncanny valley perceptions; (c) extended parallel process model responses; (d) enjoyment of the experimental task; (e) self-awareness; (f) AI trust; and (g) AI folk theory scores, but lower (h) bias against AIs, relative to participants in the Stranger-TalkingHead playback condition.

H3  Participants exposed to the pro-AI media message playback condition will show increased (a) AI-generated message identification; (b) uncanny valley perceptions; (c) extended parallel process model responses; (d) enjoyment of the experimental task; (e) self-awareness; (f) AI trust; and (g) AI folk theory scores, but lower (h) bias against AIs, relative to participants in the anti-AI media message playback condition.

RQ1  Will there be a statistical interaction between playback message (self-talking head, other talking head, and audio) and message stance manipulations (pro or anti-AI) on (a) AI-generated message identification; (b) uncanny valley perceptions; (c) extended parallel process model responses; (d) enjoyment of the experimental task; (e) self -awareness; (f) AI trust; (g) AI folk theory scores; and (h) bias against AIs?

RQ2  Do uncanny valley perceptions moderate and/or mediate the effects of pro or anti-AI persuasive messages and message delivery conditions on (a) AI-generated message identification; (b) extended parallel process model responses; (c) enjoyment of the experimental task; (d) self -awareness; (e) AI trust; (f) AI folk theory scores; and (g) bias against AIs?

q1.value: Viewing Distance and Face Recognition E4

q3.value: Past research has shown that viewing distance of a face can have a harmful impact on memory performance overall (e.g., Lampinen et al, 2015), but less is known about how viewing distance of a face influences the confidence-accuracy relationship. In previous experiments, we found that the CA relationship was impaired for high simulated distances (Gaussian blur of 10), but not for less distant faces.  The goal of this experiment was to employ a verbal warning prior to testing to see if that could alleviate the effect on CA.

q4.value: Viewing distance will have a harmful impact on memory performance, as indexed by d prime values. In the warning condition, there will not be an effect of distance on the confidence-accuracy relationship, but there will be in the no-warning condition.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a 2 (Viewing Distance: near or far) x 2 (Warning vs. No Warning) mixed design, with the former variable manipulated within-subjects and the latter manipulated between-subjects. Participants will see randomly intermixed blurred and un-blurred faces. They will then be tested on their memory for the faces (un-blurred) at test. Half of the subjects will be given a written and verbal warning about being careful with their confidence judgments prior to the test. Assignment of faces to be blurred/un-blurred and studied/new will be counterbalanced across subjects.

q9.value: Assignment of participants to each counterbalance will be determined by a random Qualtrics redirect link, and as data collection nears completion we will eliminate completed conditions from the randomizer.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q11.value: No data have been downloaded or examined prior to registration.

question.value: 100 participants will be recruited from Skidmore College's SONA participation pool, and all members of the pool will be allowed to participate. Participants will be excluded from analysis if they do not finish the experiment, do not wish to have their data saved, or do not follow instructions. Participants will be given .50 credits for participating (the standard amount of credit awarded for 0-30 minutes). Data collection will continue until 50 participants have been collected per group, with replacements for any eliminated subjects added to the total number of participants.

q13.value: 100 participants will be required, with 50 in each between-subjects condition.

q14.value: Sample size is based on a previous paper of ours (i.e., Davis, Peterson, Wissman, & Slater, in preparation) and Weber and Brewer's (2004) Experiment 1, and Study 1 of the current project.

q15.value: We will terminate data collection when we have reached the desired number of subjects. If we continue to collect data past this point (in order to fill a week of Research Assistant time), the additional data points will not be analyzed.

question.value:
Simulated Distance: Participants will see blurred (simulated distance, Gaussian Blur level 10) and un-blurred faces. Later accuracy will be determined by comparing previously blurred vs. non-blurred faces and yoked controls from new faces on the final test.

Warning: Half of participants will receive a verbal and written warning prior to taking the recognition test.

We will measure overall hits, false alarms, and compute d prime values. The difference in d prime values will be compared with a paired-samples t-test to determine the impact of simulated viewing distance on memory. Positive ("old" responses) will be analyzed and conditional accuracy will be plotted across confidence bins. The size of the confidence bins will be similar to Davis et al (2019) to the extent that there are approximately equal numbers of observations across bins.

A 2 (Distance: Near vs. Far) x 2 (Warning vs. No Warning) mixed ANOVA will be conducted on accuracy of each level of confidence.  We are also interested in the effect of distance for each level of warning, and the effect of warning at each level of viewing distance, and will pursue follow-up tests based on the outcome of the ANOVA.

We will measure memory performance overall using a 2 (Distance: Near vs. Far) x 2 (Warning vs. No Warning) mixed ANOVA on d' performance.  Follow-up comparisons will be based on the outcome of the ANOVA.

q21.value: Alpha will be set at .05, and all tests will be two-tailed. Post-hoc tests will be corrected using a Bonferroni correction.

q22.value: Incomplete data (e.g., the participant did not finish the experiment) will not be included. RA's will also be instructed to note if any participant does not appear to follow instructions, and these points will be removed.

attributes.title: Judging Fraction Magnitudes Across Symbolic and Nonsymbolic Formats

q1.value: Judging Fraction Magnitudes Across Symbolic and Nonsymbolic Formats

q3.value:
Preliminary studies indicate that human adults can successfully map nonsymbolic fraction magnitudes to symbolic fractions, albeit with consistent patterns of bias.  We seek to replicate these findings and explore biases in cross-format mappings in two types of tasks: numerical estimation and magnitude comparison. Two related studies will improve upon prior work by comparing cross-format fraction estimation and comparison performance within the same subjects. 
1. Does the finding that adults can accurately compare fractions (Matthews and Chesney, 2015) and estimate fractions (Chesney and Matthews, 2018) across symbolic and nonsymbolic formats replicate?
2. Do individuals show the same amount and direction of bias in both comparison and estimation tasks? 
3. How does cross-format fraction comparison and estimation differ depending on the nonsymbolic notation (circle ratio, line ratio, dot ratio, etc.)?

Study 1 will test cross-format comparison and estimation performance using circle ratios and line ratios as the non-symbolic formats. Study 2 will test cross-format comparison and estimation performance using ratios of heterogeneously-sized dots and homogenously-sized dots. These studies will be conducted with separate subjects due to concerns about fatigue and time constraints.

q4.value:
1. Adults will accurately compare and estimate fractions across nonsymbolic formats.
1a. Estimation: Adults will provide accurate symbolic estimates of nonsymbolic fractions presented in circle ratio, dot ratio, or line ratio formats. Their estimates will be best fit by a linear function with a slope of approximately 1 and an intercept near 0.
1b. Comparison: Adults will quickly and accurately choose the larger of two fractions across nonsymbolic and symbolic formats, with observable distance effects. Their comparison performance will be more accurate and faster for trials with a larger numerical distance between the fractions.

2. Within each format of nonsymbolic fraction (circle ratio, line ratio, homogenous dot ratio, heterogenous dot ratio), adults will show the same amount and direction of bias in both comparison and estimation tasks. For example, the average point of subjective equality in comparison of circle ratios and symbolic fractions (i.e., “the point at which participants on average judge presented stimuli as approximately equal in magnitude”) will be the same as the intercept of the best fitting line of participants’ estimates of circle ratios.

3. Cross-format comparison and estimation performance will be worst and most variable in trials with dot ratios, especially dot ratios with heterogenous dot sizes. Performance will be most accurate and least biased in trials with line ratios.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Study 1 will use a 2 x 2 within-subjects design, with factors of task (estimation and comparison) and nonsymbolic format (circle ratio and line ratio). Study 2 will use a 2 x 2 within-subjects design, with factors of task (estimation and comparison) and nonsymbolic format (heterogeneously-sized dot ratios, homogenously-sized dot ratios). In both studies, order of tasks will be counterbalanced, but participants will always complete both tasks with one nonsymbolic format before starting either task in the other format.

q9.value: These studies use within-subjects designs, so participants will receive all possible conditions.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value: Data collection began in October 2019 and is ongoing. The researchers have not observed any of the collected data (i.e., have not opened the computer-generated data files). Research assistants who were experimenters may have seen participants' answers in real-time but have had no access to the data files.

question.value:
We will recruit undergraduate students through the online Educational Psychology SONA system. Participants will receive partial course credit for participation. Participants must be over 18 and currently enrolled in an Educational Psychology course. We will begin collecting data in November and continue through the fall semester or until the desired sample size is met.

All sessions will take place in the lab. Participants will complete informed consent. Then participants will complete 4 tasks: 2 estimation tasks and 2 comparison tasks. The order of tasks will be counterbalanced, but participants will always complete both tasks with one nonsymbolic format before starting either task in the other format. In the estimation trials, they will see a nonsymbolic fraction flash briefly (1500ms) on the screen and be asked “What was the fraction?” After participants type their estimate onto the screen, they can press enter to start the next trial. In the comparison trials, participants will see a nonsymbolic ratio and a symbolic ratio flash briefly together for 1500ms. They will use a key press to indicate which fraction is larger. See “Manipulated variables” section for details about the stimuli for both tasks. Finally, participants will complete a brief demographic questionnaire.

q13.value: We will collect data from a minimum of 31 participants in each study.

q14.value: Our primary analyses will pool trials from all participants, and we will conduct secondary analyses of individual patterns to detect heterogeneity in the sample. Based on the smallest amount of variance explained by distance and symbol side in the pooled analysis of the previous comparison study, (R2 = 0.27; Matthews & Chesney, 2015), we calculated the smallest effect size that we would like to be able to detect (f2 = 0.3699). To detect this effect size with an α of .05 and power of .95, an analysis using G*Power showed that we only need 31 participants. We based our estimate on the more conservative effect size of the prior comparison study rather than the prior estimation study.

q15.value: We will stop collecting data at the end of the fall semester or when we reach 31 participants per study, whichever is later.

question.value:
Task: Comparison or Estimation
Nonsymbolic Ratio Format: Line, Circle, Heterogenous Dot, Homogenous Dot

The estimation task will include 4 different instantiations of 10 fraction magnitudes, for a total of 40 trials in each format. For example, 3/5 will be instantiated by line ratios of 22/27 (pixels), 70/117, 38/63, and 43/71. The 10 fractions were chosen to span the space from 0.2 to 0.9: 2/9, 2/7, 3/8, 3/7, 5/9, 3/5, 2/3, 3/4, 5/6, 7/8. See attached spreadsheet for a full list of estimation stimuli.

The comparison task will include the same 10 fraction magnitudes (2/9, 2/7, 3/8, 3/7, 5/9, 3/5, 2/3, 3/4, 5/6, 7/8). Each fraction will be compared to itself and each of the other 9 magnitudes twice, once with the symbolic instantiation on the left and once with the symbolic instantiation on the right, yielding a total of 200 comparison trials. Therefore, we will control the numerical distance between each fraction pair.

For both tasks, the 4 nonsymbolic instantiations of each magnitude include 2 that were created as part of a set with numerators uncorrelated with the overall fraction magnitude and 2 that were created as part of a set with denominators uncorrelated with the overall fraction magnitude. This reduces the possibility that participants will make decisions based only on one component of the fraction, instead of attending to the fraction as a whole. In both tasks, participants will see trials with nonsymbolic ratios from the “uncorrelated numerators” set for the first half of the task and trials with nonsymbolic ratios from the “uncorrelated denominators” set for the second half of the task, or vice versa.

Estimated Fraction Magnitude: The participants’ responses for each estimation trial will be converted to a decimal magnitude, which we can compare to the actual magnitude of the nonsymbolic fraction.

Comparison Accuracy: Score 1 if participant correctly chose the larger of two fractions, Score 0 if participant was incorrect. All trials with equal fractions will receive a 0.

Comparison Reaction Time (RT): How quickly did participant decide which fraction was larger?

Demographic variables: Age, Sex, Major, Ethnic Category, Racial Category
Estimation performance will be indexed for some analyses by Percent Absolute Error: 100*(|estimated magnitude – actual magnitude|).

To test hypothesis 1a, we will regress participants’ estimated magnitudes on the actual magnitude of the given fraction and the nonsymbolic format of the given fraction. 

To test hypothesis 1b, we will regress RT on the absolute numerical distance between the fractions, the nonsymbolic format, a dummy code for symbolic fraction on the right side of the pair, and an interaction term between numerical distance and symbol side. For this test we will only use RT of correct trials. We will also run a logistic regression to predict accuracy of the trial from numerical distance, nonsymbolic format, symbol side, and an interaction between numerical distance and symbol side. 

To test hypothesis 2, we will calculate the Point of Subjective Equality in comparison for each format and compare it to the intercept of the best fitting line of participants’ estimates for the corresponding format. To calculate the Point of Subjective Equality, we will use logistic regression to predict the probability that participants judged the symbolic fraction as larger than the nonsymbolic fraction. This logistic regression will use the numerical difference between the symbolic fraction magnitude and the nonsymbolic fraction magnitude, the side the symbolic fraction is on, and an interaction term between numerical difference and symbol side as predictors. Then, the point at which the logistic regression predicts 50% probability of judging the symbolic fraction as larger is the Point of Subjective Equality, at which participants perceive the symbolic and nonsymbolic fractions to be the same value. 

A test of hypothesis 3 is embedded in the format effect parameters of the previous analyses.

q22.value: We will cut comparison trials with RTs that are more than 3 standard deviations beyond the mean RT. We will also cut participants who failed to follow directions (e.g., by systematically choosing the smaller of the two fractions).

Within each format of nonsymbolic fraction (circle ratio, line ratio, homogenous dot ratio, heterogenous dot ratio), adults will show the same amount and direction of bias in both comparison and estimation tasks. For example, the average point of subjective equality in comparison of circle ratios and symbolic fractions (i.e., “the point at which participants on average judge presented stimuli as approximately equal in magnitude”) will be the same as the intercept of the best fitting line of participants’ estimates of circle ratios.

3. Cross-format comparison and estimation performance will be worst and most variable in trials with dot ratios, especially dot ratios with heterogenous dot sizes. Performance will be most accurate and least biased in trials with line ratios.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q9: These studies use within-subjects designs, so participants will receive all possible conditions.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to accessing the data
registration_responses.q11: Data collection began in October 2019 and is ongoing. The researchers have not observed any of the collected data (i.e., have not opened the computer-generated data files). Research assistants who were experimenters may have seen participants' answers in real-time but have had no access to the data files.
registration_responses.q13: We will collect data from a minimum of 31 participants in each study.
registration_responses.q14: Our primary analyses will pool trials from all participants, and we will conduct secondary analyses of individual patterns to detect heterogeneity in the sample. Based on the smallest amount of variance explained by distance and symbol side in the pooled analysis of the previous comparison study, (R2 = 0.27; Matthews & Chesney, 2015), we calculated the smallest effect size that we would like to be able to detect (f2 = 0.3699). To detect this effect size with an α of .05 and power of .95, an analysis using G*Power showed that we only need 31 participants. We based our estimate on the more conservative effect size of the prior comparison study rather than the prior estimation study.
registration_responses.q15: We will stop collecting data at the end of the fall semester or when we reach 31 participants per study, whichever is later.
registration_responses.q22: We will cut comparison trials with RTs that are more than 3 standard deviations beyond the mean RT. We will also cut participants who failed to follow directions (e.g., by systematically choosing the smaller of the two fractions).
registration_responses.q8.question: Study 1 will use a 2 x 2 within-subjects design, with factors of task (estimation and comparison) and nonsymbolic format (circle ratio and line ratio). Study 2 will use a 2 x 2 within-subjects design, with factors of task (estimation and comparison) and nonsymbolic format (heterogeneously-sized dot ratios, homogenously-sized dot ratios). In both studies, order of tasks will be counterbalanced, but participants will always complete both tasks with one nonsymbolic format before starting either task in the other format.
registration_responses.q12.question:
We will recruit undergraduate students through the online Educational Psychology SONA system. Participants will receive partial course credit for participation. Participants must be over 18 and currently enrolled in an Educational Psychology course. We will begin collecting data in November and continue through the fall semester or until the desired sample size is met.

All sessions will take place in the lab. Participants will complete informed consent. Then participants will complete 4 tasks: 2 estimation tasks and 2 comparison tasks. The order of tasks will be counterbalanced, but participants will always complete both tasks with one nonsymbolic format before starting either task in the other format. In the estimation trials, they will see a nonsymbolic fraction flash briefly (1500ms) on the screen and be asked “What was the fraction?” After participants type their estimate onto the screen, they can press enter to start the next trial. In the comparison trials, participants will see a nonsymbolic ratio and a symbolic ratio flash briefly together for 1500ms. They will use a key press to indicate which fraction is larger. See “Manipulated variables” section for details about the stimuli for both tasks. Finally, participants will complete a brief demographic questionnaire.
registration_responses.q16.question:
Task: Comparison or Estimation
Nonsymbolic Ratio Format: Line, Circle, Heterogenous Dot, Homogenous Dot

The estimation task will include 4 different instantiations of 10 fraction magnitudes, for a total of 40 trials in each format. For example, 3/5 will be instantiated by line ratios of 22/27 (pixels), 70/117, 38/63, and 43/71. The 10 fractions were chosen to span the space from 0.2 to 0.9: 2/9, 2/7, 3/8, 3/7, 5/9, 3/5, 2/3, 3/4, 5/6, 7/8. See attached spreadsheet for a full list of estimation stimuli.

The comparison task will include the same 10 fraction magnitudes (2/9, 2/7, 3/8, 3/7, 5/9, 3/5, 2/3, 3/4, 5/6, 7/8). Each fraction will be compared to itself and each of the other 9 magnitudes twice, once with the symbolic instantiation on the left and once with the symbolic instantiation on the right, yielding a total of 200 comparison trials. Therefore, we will control the numerical distance between each fraction pair.

For both tasks, the 4 nonsymbolic instantiations of each magnitude include 2 that were created as part of a set with numerators uncorrelated with the overall fraction magnitude and 2 that were created as part of a set with denominators uncorrelated with the overall fraction magnitude. This reduces the possibility that participants will make decisions based only on one component of the fraction, instead of attending to the fraction as a whole. In both tasks, participants will see trials with nonsymbolic ratios from the “uncorrelated numerators” set for the first half of the task and trials with nonsymbolic ratios from the “uncorrelated denominators” set for the second half of the task, or vice versa.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Estimated Fraction Magnitude: The participants’ responses for each estimation trial will be converted to a decimal magnitude, which we can compare to the actual magnitude of the nonsymbolic fraction.

Comparison Accuracy: Score 1 if participant correctly chose the larger of two fractions, Score 0 if participant was incorrect. All trials with equal fractions will receive a 0.

Comparison Reaction Time (RT): How quickly did participant decide which fraction was larger?

Demographic variables: Age, Sex, Major, Ethnic Category, Racial Category
registration_responses.q18.question: Estimation performance will be indexed for some analyses by Percent Absolute Error: 100*(|estimated magnitude – actual magnitude|).
registration_responses.q19.question:
To test hypothesis 1a, we will regress participants’ estimated magnitudes on the actual magnitude of the given fraction and the nonsymbolic format of the given fraction. 

To test hypothesis 1b, we will regress RT on the absolute numerical distance between the fractions, the nonsymbolic format, a dummy code for symbolic fraction on the right side of the pair, and an interaction term between numerical distance and symbol side. For this test we will only use RT of correct trials. We will also run a logistic regression to predict accuracy of the trial from numerical distance, nonsymbolic format, symbol side, and an interaction between numerical distance and symbol side. 

To test hypothesis 2, we will calculate the Point of Subjective Equality in comparison for each format and compare it to the intercept of the best fitting line of participants’ estimates for the corresponding format. To calculate the Point of Subjective Equality, we will use logistic regression to predict the probability that participants judged the symbolic fraction as larger than the nonsymbolic fraction. This logistic regression will use the numerical difference between the symbolic fraction magnitude and the nonsymbolic fraction magnitude, the side the symbolic fraction is on, and an interaction term between numerical difference and symbol side as predictors. Then, the point at which the logistic regression predicts 50% probability of judging the symbolic fraction as larger is the Point of Subjective Equality, at which participants perceive the symbolic and nonsymbolic fractions to be the same value. 

A test of hypothesis 3 is embedded in the format effect parameters of the previous analyses.

attributes.title: Moral Values' Impact on Responses to NFL Protests

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Moral values & attitudes about social justice protest - Study 3

sample.value: We will collect a sample of 250 participants.

analyses.value:
We will conduct four independent samples t-tests, one for each of our key dependent variables. Specifically, we will test for differences between the fairness and authority prime conditions on: (1) the composite motive measure, (2) the composite trait measure, (3) the moral judgment (blame-praise) measure, and (4) the composite measure of support for eight forms of protest.

Additionally, we will conduct one independent samples t-test on the authority-fairness composite measure (created by subtracting participants’ fairness values from their authority values on the MFQ) to test whether the participants in the fairness vs. the authority conditions differed in the degree to which they preferentially endorsed fairness or authority values after the manipulation.

outliers.value:
We will exclude participants based on two criteria. First, we will exclude participants If they fail fail both of the attention check questions embedded in the MFQ.
(1) responding that "Whether or not someone was good at math" is "slightly relevant " or more (i.e., a 2-5 on the scale)
(2) responding that they "disagree" (i.e., a 0-2) to the question: "It is better to do good than to do bad. " 

Second we will exclude participants if they respond affirmatively to the suspicion check question at the end of the experiment: "Was there anything in this experiment that made you suspicious? "

dependent.value:
We have four key dependent variables: 

(1) a six item measure of perceived motive, each measured on a 1 (strongly disagree) – 7 (strongly agree) Likert scale. The order of the specific items will be randomized for each participant. We'll reverse score the negatively worded items (2,4,5) and average the six items into a single composite motive measure.
Exact wording for each of the items is below:
"To what extent do you agree or disagree with the following descriptions of the protesters' motives?"
The protesters want to draw attention to an important social issue
The protesters want to cause trouble 
The protesters are trying to fight for racial equality
The protesters want to disrespect the police
The protesters are trying to be destructive 
The protesters are trying to support their community 
 
(2) a six item measure of perceived traits, each measured on a 1 (strongly disagree) – 7 (strongly agree) Likert scale. The order of the specific items will be randomized for each participant. We'll reverse score the negatively worded items (2,4,5) and average the six items into a single composite trait measure.
Exact wording for each of the items is below:
"To what extent do you agree or disagree with the following descriptions about the protesters?" 
The protesters are self-sacrificing
The protesters are destructive
The protesters are patriotic
The protesters are anti-American
The protesters are arrogant 
The protesters are people to be proud of

(3) a single-item measure moral judgment measured asking "Do you feel the protesters deserve any blame or praise for their behavior?" measured on a -5 (a lot of blame) – 5 (a lot of praise)  scale.

(4) an eight item-measure capturing support for varying forms of social justice protest. Each item was measured on a 1 (completely inappropriate) – 5 (completely appropriate)  scale. The order of the specific items will be randomized for each participant. We'll average responses to the eight items into a single composite 'protest support' measure.
Exact wording for each of the items is below:
"How appropriate or inappropriate do you think it would be for African Americans to engage in the following forms of protest?"
Marching in a protest 
Wearing protest-related clothing (e.g., a shirt that says "can't breathe" 
Criticizing elected officials on social media
Staging a sit-in
Kneeling during the National Anthem 
Staging acts of civil disobedience  
Boycotting companies
Going on strike at their workplace 

Finally at the end of the experiment participants will respond to the moral foundations questionnaire (MFQ, Graham, Haidt, & Nosek, 2009) to measure people endorsement of fairness and authority moral values. We'll use responses on the MFQ create an authority-fairness composite variable by subtracting the fairness scores from the authority scores.

conditions.value: We have two conditions: a fairness prime and a respect-for-authority prime condition.  Participants will be randomly assigned to one of these two conditions.

hypothesis.value: This experiment tests a moral tradeoff hypothesis, which stipulates that experimentally inducing people to prioritize fairness moral values over respect for authority values will increase positive motive and trait attributions, improve moral judgments of protesters, and increase support for diverse forms of social justice protests

q1.value: Perceptions of bullying : Does framing affect attitudes?

q3.value: Although extensive research has documented the prevalence of bullying and its negative effects, little is known about public perceptions of bullying. In order to promote policy and legislative changes geared at preventing bullying and its negative effects, it is important to identify how public framing of bullying may impact public attitudes. The current study experimentally tests whether young adults' attitudes towards bullying vary depending on the messaging of bullying-related research.

q4.value:
1. It is hypothesized that participants will show less favorable attitudes towards bullying (i.e., antibullying) and more strongly support antibullying policies when they learn about research highlighting the negative consequences of bullying (3 of the conditions) compared to research highlighting the overall prevalence of bullying (1 of the conditions). 

2. Among those who read about the negative consequences of bullying, it is hypothesized that participants will report the least favorable attitudes towards bullying (i.e., most strongly antibullying) and the most antibullying policy support when they learn about its negative effects on youth physical health outcomes (compared to mental health or academic outcomes), and that they will report less favorable attitudes towards bullying when they learn about its negative effects on youth mental health compared to academic consequences.

3. It is hypothesized that participants will be more interested in learning more about bullying research (as indicated by a behavioral choice at end of study) when they read an article excerpt highlighting the negative consequences of bullying (3 of the conditions) compared to an article highlighting the overall prevalence of bullying (1 of the conditions). 

4. Among those who read about the negative consequences of bullying, it is hypothesized that participants will be most likely to request additional information about the bullying research when they learn about its negative effects on youth physical health outcomes (compared to mental health or academic outcomes), and that they will be more likely to request additional bullying research information when they learn about its negative effects on youth mental health compared to academic consequences.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Between subjects design with 1 factor (bullying framing) and 4 levels (prevalence, mental health consequences, physical health consequences, academic consequences).

q9.value: Participants were randomly assigned to one of the four conditions in Qualtrics using the Randomizer function with "evenly present elements" option selected.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value: Data collection has been underway for 4 days as of this preregistration. After the first 10 participants completed the surveys on Qualtrics on day 1 of data collection, their data were downloaded to double-check that the randomization procedure was performing correctly. Participants' responses to survey questions/scales were not examined during this check, nor have they been since. As of today, 77 participants have completed the study on Qualtrics.

question.value: Data are collected through Qualtrics. Participants are eligible for the study if they are current undergraduate students at Wayne State University between the ages of 18-25 enrolled in the Psychology subject pool. However, undergraduates who are current students in the lead researcher's psychology course are not eligible to participate. The study was posted on the psychology subject pool website on Monday, January 6th 2020 and will remain open until the end of the semester (April 2020). Participants receive .5 research credits for their participation.

q13.value: The desired sample size is approximately 300 participants.

q14.value: Power analyses in G*Power prior to study initiation indicated that a sample of 280 would provide 95% power to detect medium sized effects (f=.25). Given that some participants may fail the attention check, we conservatively aim for 300.

q15.value: We will terminate data collection once the sample size reaches 300 or the end of the semester (April 21, 2020), whichever comes first.

question.value:
All participants are instructed to read a research summary about bullying. We manipulate the content of the research summary across 4 conditions. Specifically...

CONDITION 1: summary of recent research documenting the prevalence of bullying among young people
CONDITION 2: summary of recent research documenting the negative mental health effects of bullying among young people
CONDITION 3: summary of recent research documenting the negative physical health effects of bullying among young people
CONDITION 4: summary of recent research documenting the negative academic effects of bullying among young people.

Detailed instructions and research summaries for each condition are provided in the attached document (BAB Preregistration Measures Materials).

Manipulation check: Participants are presented with a multiple choice question asking them the topic of the article they just read (see attached measures). We will calculate the percentage of participants that answered correctly.

Attention check: Participants are presented with a multiple choice question asking them a detail about the content of the article they just read (see attached measures). We will calculate the percentage of participants that answered correctly and exclude those who answered incorrectly from subsequent analyses.

Main Outcomes:
1. Antibullying policy support: Participants respond to 6 items on a 1-5 scale ranging from "strongly oppose" to "strongly support". Each item asks about a specific policy designed to address/reduce bullying, such as creating federal legislation against bullying or requiring K-12 teachers to receive training in handling bullying situations. These items were adapted from items used in a study examining public framing effects for childhood obesity (Gollust, Niederdeppe, & Barry, 2013; American Journal of Public Health).  Participants' responses to the 6 items will be averaged to create a mean score, with higher scores indicating greater support for antibullying policy support. This is the antibullying policy support measure that will be used in confirmatory analyses. We may examine differences on individual items as a function of the intervention in supplemental exploratory analyses (e.g., to see if people assigned to the academic consequences condition see school/teacher-related policy change as particularly important).
 
2. Bullying-related attitudes: Participants respond to 11 items on a 1-5 scale ranging from "totally false" to "totally true" (see attached Materials document for full list). These items were adapted from Swearer and Carey's 2003 Bully Survey (Part D; Journal of Applied School Psychology) to be more age-appropriate among young adults (as opposed to children/adolescents). The items, which capture participants' general attitudes about bullying (e.g., Most people who get bullied ask for it; Being bullied is no big deal), will be averaged into a single mean score with higher values indicating more anti-bullying attitudes (i.e., less favorable attitudes towards bullying).

3. At the end of the study, participants are asked whether they would like to receive additional information about the bullying research they read before (yes=1/no=0). This behavioral measure was intended to gauge whether participants' are more compelled to learn more about bullying depending on the specific type of research they read about.
See above.

Confirmatory analyses:

1. One-way ANOVA with IV as framing condition (4 levels) and the DV as antibullying policy support; Tukey post-hoc effects test to examine group differences.
2. One-way ANOVA with IV as framing condition (4 levels) and the DV as bullying attitudes; Tukey post-hoc effects test to examine group differences.
3. Logistic regression with 3 dummy-coded condition predictors and rotating reference group to determine any group differences on behavioral measure (whether or not participants request more information about the bullying research they read about).

q20.value: Positively worded (i.e., probullying) items on the Bullying Attitudes scale will be reverse coded before a summary score is created so that for all items higher scores reflect more antibullying attitudes  (i.e., less favorable attitudes towards bullying).

q21.value: P-values will be set at .05 for all analyses. All tests will be two tailed.

q22.value: Participants will be excluded from all analyses if they fail the attention check.

q23.value: Analyses will be run with the maximum number of observations available. Thus, if a participant completes the bullying attitudes scale but not the antibullying policy support scale, they will still be included in the bullying attitudes ANOVA. Mean scores for each scale will be calculated based upon whatever item-level data are available.

q24.value:
1. We may examine whether the results change if we add participants' own prior (self-reported) peer victimization as a covariate in ANOVAs (i.e., ANCOVA)/logistic regression.

2. We may examine whether the results change if we add participants' political affiliation as a covariate in ANOVAs (i.e., ANCOVA)/logistic regression.

3. We may examine whether the results change if we add participants' gender as a covariate and/or moderator in ANOVAs (i.e., ANCOVA)/logistic regression.

registration_responses.q18.question: See above.
registration_responses.q19.question:
Confirmatory analyses:

1. One-way ANOVA with IV as framing condition (4 levels) and the DV as antibullying policy support; Tukey post-hoc effects test to examine group differences.
2. One-way ANOVA with IV as framing condition (4 levels) and the DV as bullying attitudes; Tukey post-hoc effects test to examine group differences.
3. Logistic regression with 3 dummy-coded condition predictors and rotating reference group to determine any group differences on behavioral measure (whether or not participants request more information about the bullying research they read about).

attributes.title: Somatosensory aspects of mandibular motor control in adults who do and do not stutter
attributes.description:
A broad range of physiological and behavioral research has demonstrated that people who stutter (PWS) have deficits in the ability to process auditory feedback and utilize it in the regulation of speech motor control. Atypical features of central neurophysiology include diminished grey matter development and integrity of white matter tracts between key auditory processing and premotor areas involved in speech planning and production (Beal 2015; Kell et al. 2009; Chang et al. 2008; Watkins et al. 2008; Chang et al. 2018; Neef et al. 2015). Characteristic modulation of auditory cortical activity immediately prior to speech production is also absent in PWS (Daliri & Max 2015a, 2015b; Daliri & Max 2018), which may reflect inefficient priming of sensory cortices necessary to detect unexpected feedback errors in the upcoming utterance (Eliades & Wang 2008; Eliades & Tsunada 2018). Indeed, there is a wide range of evidence showing that PWS have reduced adaptive speech responses to predictable auditory feedback perturbations (Daliri et al. 2018 [adults only]; Daliri & Max 2018), as well as diminished online responses to unexpected single-trial perturbations (Cai et al. 2012; Loucks et al. 2012). Thus, the dysregulated cortical network connectivity in PWS appears to manifest as a specific deficit in auditory feedback processing for the regulation of ongoing speech motor control.
Conversely, less is known about the ability of PWS to process somatosensory feedback in the regulation of orofacial movement control. In people who do not stutter (PWNS), the role of somatosensation has been demonstrated through jaw and orofacial kinematic responses to both predictable (Nasir & Ostry 2006; Tremblay et al. 2003; 2008; Lametti et al. 2012; Feng et al. 2011) and unexpected online (Abbs & Gracco 1984, Folins & Abbs 1975; Tiede et al. 2006) physical perturbations to the articulators during speech and non-speech movements. However, the profile of these responses in PWS is unknown. Clearly there are structural abnormalities in the neural connections between auditory processing and speech motor cortical areas in PWS, but there are also specific abnormalities within (pre-)motor areas which may limit integration of other sensory signals for speech motor control too (for reviews see Neef 2015; Chang 2018). Given that PWS also show atypical movement characteristics during basic non-speech movement control (Daliri, Propenko, Flanagan & Max 2015; Forster & Webster 2001; Max, Caruso & Gracco 2003), it may be that they experience generalized sensory processing difficulties which affect multiple sensory domains and effector systems. Alternatively, it could be that somatic sensorimotor processing is relatively intact for PWS and that stuttering arises from problems specific to auditory-motor integration or a conflict between somatosensory and auditory processing during speech motor control.
As such, this project broadly aims to investigate how PWS differ from neurotypical controls in their ability to integrate somatosensory feedback in the regulation of mandibular speech and non-speech movement control.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Speech motor adaptation to mandibular force-field perturbations in adults who stutter.

other.value:
Acoustic speech data will also be recorded for each participant, which will allow us to analyze any potential modifications of acoustic speech output during the different stages of the experiment that may have additionally contributed to the observed adaptation effects on jaw trajectories. This will include tracking the first and second vowel formant frequencies taken from the central portion of the vowel sound, as well as the first 4 spectral coefficients (mean, standard deviation, skewness and kurtosis) for the entire selected vowel. 
We will also track and compare the peak jaw opening displacement and peak velocity across the experiment to assess the consistency of force magnitude exposure across trials and between groups.

sample.value: There will be two groups of participants; (1) at least 12 adults who do not stutter, and (2) the same number of age-, hand-, and sex-matched adults who do stutter. All participants will perform the same experimental paradigm.

analyses.value: Independent samples t-tests will be used to assess potential differences between the adults who stutter (AWS) and adults do not stutter (AWNS) with respect to dependent variables described.

outliers.value: Data from incomplete experimental protocols or other extenuating circumstances (misunderstanding of instructions, technical or measurement errors) will not be included in final analysis, but the number of such cases will be disclosed as necessary. Specific trials may be excluded on the basis of producing the incorrect target word (or not producing a word at all), as well as coughing or other means of confounding the typical acoustic and kinematic productions of the target word. Exact proportion of trials excluded on these bases will also be disclosed as necessary.

hypothesis.value: Do adults who stutter differ from those who do not in the ability to utilize somatosensory feedback for jaw kinematic adaptation during speech production.
